thread.title: From Jeff to Jess: The transgender mayor running a small town in Texas
thread.title_full: From Jeff to Jess: The transgender mayor running a small town in Texas

author: Zoe Ferguson
title: From Jeff to Jess: The transgender mayor running a small town in Texas
text:
Map: United States 
When Jess Herbst became mayor of the small Texan town New Hope in 2016, her colleagues only knew her as 'Jeff'. 
Despite beginning hormone replacement therapy in February 2015, Mrs Herbst's female identity was still a secret from her work and community until last week. 
She began coming out to people in New Hope by door knocking and meeting people face-to-face, before publishing an open letter on the town's website . 
"If I'm going to be the mayor, I work for them and I cannot do that unless I'm absolutely honest as possible," she said. 
"There's no way I could sit there at the council meetings pretending to be Jeff when the rest of the time I was not — I was Jess. 
"The only way [the public] can trust me is if I give them everything, if I give them who I am — I'm not hiding anything." 
Ms Herbst has worked in local politics since 2003 and was appointed New Hope's mayor last year after the elected mayor died from a heart attack. 
"By the time you decide to transition and come out, you've gone through years of nerve-wracking and fear and [worrying] about what will happen when you step out of the house," she said. 'I wasn't trying to make history' 
Ms Herbst's honesty policy ensured her stamp on history in becoming the first transgender mayor in the conservative state. 
"I don't think that this would be history if I were in any other place in the world, even other states in the United States," she said. 
"But people perceive the state of Texas as being so far to the right, so conservative, that they just seemed shocked by it. 
"I wasn't trying to make history, I was just trying to be real and be honest." 
Coming out publicly as transgender has been well received by the community and Mrs Herbst's own family. 
"I've been married for 36 years [and] my wife has known of my tendencies since before we were married," she said. 
"It would be unfair to say that she knew I was transgender; at that point I didn't know the word 'transgender' and neither did she. 
Ms Herbst said she kept the change from her daughters until they were 18. 
"My eldest daughter I told first and she was on my side instantly," she said. 
Ms Herbst's political priorities include protecting the rights and safety of transgender individuals. 
She has come out strongly against the so-called 'bathroom bill' which, if passed by the Texas legislature, prohibits transgender people using public toilets corresponding with their gender identity. 
"There is no merit whatsoever to the bathroom bill — they've never found anyone that has ever attacked anyone, as much as they tried. 
"It [the bathroom bill] has crippled North Carolina and it'll do the same thing to Texas."
